articles.title: Prevalent Emotions in Mainstream Music, by Decade
articles.description: An exploration of emotions in popular music
articles.contents:
Introduction
We can all agree that music is constantly changing. New genres and
styles emerge constantly, creating experimental and inventive sounds.
This project aims to visualize the change in emotion over time in
popular music.
First things first, let’s take a look at our data, pulled with the
spotifyr and billboard packages.




At this point, you might be wondering what valence and energy are.
Lets go to Spotify for the explanations.
Energy is a measure from 0.0 to 1.0 and represents a perceptual
measure of intensity and activity. Typically, energetic tracks feel
fast, loud, and noisy. For example, death metal has high energy, while a
Bach prelude scores low on the scale.
Valence is measure from 0.0 to 1.0 describing the musical
positiveness conveyed by a track. Tracks with high valence sound more
positive (e.g. happy, cheerful, euphoric), while tracks with low valence
sound more negative (e.g. sad, depressed, angry).
So, by these definitions, we can conclude a few things. Tracks with
high energy but low valence can be classified as angry, and a track with
low energy but high valence could be considered calm, or peaceful. The
other two extremes here would belong to sad and happy tracks.
Let’s plot it!
Plotting



This graph might look a little confusing at first, but let me
explain. In each corner of the graphs, lies the extreme for a certain
emotion. The top right contains happiness, the top left anger, the
bottom left sadness, and the bottom right calmness.
We can see that over the past few decades music has drifted toward
our ‘angry’ corner in the top left. Let’s make this trend a little
clearer with a formula used by Evan
Oppenheimer here.
Sonic Anger Index = sqrt((1 - valence) * energy)
Using this equation, the more angry a song is, the closer our value
is to one.



Here we can see a clear incline in ‘angry’ music since the 60s!
